headline: Who's Talking to Chris Wallace
subHeadline: Interview With Mark Cuban; Interview With George Clooney. Aired 7-8p ET

utterances.speaker: RENE MARSH, CNN NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: But it could be decades before it's available for widescale use. And by that time, the climate crisis could have reached a tipping point.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much for joining me this evening. I'm Pamela Brown, wishing you happy holidays. "WHO'S TALKING TO CHRIS WALLACE?" is up next.

utterances.speaker: CHRIS WALLACE, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Welcome back to WHO'S TALKING.Tonight, we're doing something different. As our first season comes to a close, we want to take a fresh look at two of your favorite guests so far and pull back the curtain even more, including something you may not have seen from actor and director George Clooney. The revelation that his career in Hollywood almost didn't happen. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: GEORGE CLOONEY, ACTOR AND FILMMAKER
utterances.sentences: The door was open for me so I got a jump ahead of other people and I was terrible at it.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But first billionaire Mark Cuban tells us how his time on TV's smash hit "Shark Tank" could be running out. Tonight, more from our conversation as we dig into that moment they struck it rich.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: How did it feel at age 41 to be a billionaire?

utterances.speaker: MARK CUBAN, BILLIONAIRE ENTREPRENEUR
utterances.sentences: Really good.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You've had a few clunkers in recent years.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: You think?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: That's not perception. That's reality.

utterances.speaker: SHANIA TWAIN, SINGER
utterances.sentences: I've been feeling stronger than ever now in my life.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: How would you rate yourself as a chef?

utterances.speaker: TYLER PERRY, COMEDIAN
utterances.sentences: Wow, I'm not doing that with you, Christopher Wallace.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Mark Cuban is known as a billionaire investor, a successful NBA owner and a shark on one of TV's most popular shows. Tonight we take a close look on what motivates him and the new project he says could be life-changing and life-saving for so many.(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I have got to start with "Shark Tank," because I've got to tell you, when I'm getting ready for bed, every night, I put on "Shark Tank" and I watch at least one pitch, and I don't know, that somehow calms me down and gets me ready to go to bed. This is your 13th season. The question is, is it good for your business? Is it an ego boost? Or is it just for fun?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Really, the reason I do the show is it sends a message to the entire country that watches that the American dream still is alive and well. And particularly for kids. You know, there aren't a lot of business classes, particularly at the lower grades, and I can't tell you how many times people come up to me and said, you know, when I was 12 years old or 13 years old, I started watching "Shark Tank" and I've started my own business and have been successful. Or my kids and I watch "Shark Tank" because it's the only show we can watch together as a family. So just sending that message and educating kids, that's the ego boost I like.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You have had some interesting moments over the years. Let's take a look.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Sure.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: She's a gold digger.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No. She's not a gold digger.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Did you just call me a gold digger?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Is this going to be as fast as last season's Dallas Mavericks playoff highlight reel? I believe --

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Can I just say that highlight reel -- oh, wait, you don't have a team, you don't have any highlights of anything, do you? You know what's going to screw you up, Kash? The fact that you believe in your own nonsense. At some point, you've got to do the work. Be somebody who doesn't get (EXPLETIVE DELETED), bro.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: What is up with that rim?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I hope the league doesn't see this.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Wow, he does suck.(END VIDEO CLIP) (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: You're killing me, Chris. You're killing me.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: No, we had our staff go through 13 seasons and find the most embarrassing moments.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: That's funny.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Over -- and you're just into your 13th season. Over these years, you say that you've invested more than $29 million in some 85 companies. What's your best investment? What's your worst investment?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: I think my best investment is a company called Cycloramic, which did computer vision. Started off just doing panoramic video on an iPhone 5 and then expanded into computer vision. They got sold to Carvana and we killed it. It was really, really good.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, you say you killed it. What did you invest?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: I think I invested $250,000 and ended up with $22 million.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You ended up --

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Why didn't you call me?(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And what was the worst investment?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: There's a long list of really bad ones. Sometimes, you know, sometimes you invest in the entrepreneurs as opposed to the business. And I've had entrepreneurs take the money and not even show up from there. And so I've had a few stinkers along the way.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So speaking of stinkers, you've had some uncomfortable moments. Those were the comfortable moments.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You've had some uncomfortable moments on "Shark Tank." Let's look at one of them.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Uh-oh.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RICHARD BRANSON, VIRGIN GROUP
utterances.sentences: Could we possibly come in with $300,000 and maybe for 10 percent?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: No, no, no, Sir Richard Branson. It has to be 600.

utterances.speaker: BRANSON
utterances.sentences: Oh, OK, I think the water just has to --(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Let me tell you what I think --

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: That was a moment.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You looked genuinely ticked off there. Were you?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: I was, I was.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You supposedly said after that that you never want to be in the same room with Sir Richard again. Is that true?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Not quite like that. I was just like, it's not something I'd look forward to.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Have you been in the same room with him?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: No, I have not. I have not. I haven't talked to him since. Not a word.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: What's your relationship like with the other sharks, particularly Mr. Wonderful?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: We're family. We really, really are. We get together, we go to each other's birthdays, go out to dinner, hang out. And Kevin, you know, he's a self-described Mr. Wonderful, but he's a good guy.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, let's talk about your being an entrepreneur, and I don't mean being on somebody else's back. You are famous for getting cold e-mails and your Gmail address is pretty well known.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And you get cold e-mails, pitches, and one of them, a couple of years ago, got you going into something called Cost Plus Drugs. Now what is that? CUBANwho wanted to create a compounding pharmacy that would offer drugs less expensively than they could be currently bought, particularly generics. And I'm like, that's a great idea, but let's do it a little differently. So we started costplusdrugs.com. And the challenge with the pharmaceutical industry is the lack of trust. It is so obfuscated, it is so dark, you know, no one really knows what anything costs, no one really knows why things are done. So I made the decision, let's create some radical transparency in Cost Plus Drugs. So if you go to costplusdrugs.com and put in whatever medication that you take you'll not end up --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Now we're talking about generics.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: We'll be adding branded drugs, and I expect that that's not going to stop. We'll keep on adding more and more. But initially now we're up to about 859,000 generic drugs.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: OK. So you say you go in, you put down the drug you want.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: We put the name in. Right. And when it comes up, then not only will you see the price that we sell it for, but you'll see the price that we pay for it. So if we pay $10, we mark it up 15 percent, so the price of the drug becomes $11.50. Then we add $3 for pharmacy handling fee and $5 for shipping. That's it. And by doing it and taking that approach, you can see what our markups are, obviously, but it ends up being so much less expensive than anywhere else. We're often saving people 70 percent, 80 percent, 90 percent.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: All right. I mean, obviously I was going to ask you that. You talk about the relatively low markup. How much -- if I go to my drugstore and I want to get a generic drug, what's it going to cost me at my drugstore as opposed to getting it from Cost Plus Drugs?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: It depends on the prescription, who prescribed it and where you're picking it up because a lot of times, you know, I said there's no transparency in the drug industry. The pharmacists often don't even know what the price is going to be when you walk in and hand them the prescription or go in to pick up your prescription. They just see the price that's being charged and they charge it to you.And so often, particularly in the big retail chains, there's things that we'll sell for $7, $8, that they'll try to charge $300 for. I mean --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Not really?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: No, for real. For real. Like there's -- I always pronounce imatinib, and imatinib, you know, as some words you can't just get them out, right?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: But it's for leukemia. So a drug for leukemia. And the retail price is $2,000. And the discount price that a lot of major pharmacies --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: This is, what, for a month's supply or?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, a month's supply of pills, right, for leukemia patients.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: OK. Yes.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: And the retail price will be $2,000. Their discounted price might be $995. And ours is $39.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I mean, that's not just a matter of savings, that's a matter of life and death.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: It's life changing.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I hear, and please tell me as a "Shark Tank" fan that this is not true, that you are so committed to Cost Plus Drugs that you are considering leaving the show?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, and it's not so much Cost Plus Drugs as it is having a daughter who just went away to college. When they're all in high school and went to the same two schools, all of our schedules could be worked out together. But it was more a question of wanting to spend more time with my family. But they came to me, and made me promise I'd come back for at least one more season.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But --

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: After that, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I read somewhere that you said the upside of being Mark Cuban, of having my wealth, is obvious, but there's also a downside because -- get the quote right, you, quote, "kind of lost that piss and vinegar."

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: I think I said that before Cost Plus Drugs. You know, costplusdrugs.com has really revitalized my energy, if you will, because as I said the opportunity to change the pharmaceutical industry in a way that makes it more affordable, so that people are healthier, that people don't have to make these choices, what's better than that? And if what I leave to my kids is just people asking them -- I remember -- or telling them, I remember when your dad started Cost Plus Drugs, and the impact it had on me. That's a piss and vinegar builder.(LAUGHTER) (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: So literally I would go door to door with a box of garbage bags and be like, hi, my name is Mark. Do you use garbage bags?(END VIDEO CLIP) (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Mark Cuban became a billionaire overnight after selling his online audio streaming service to Yahoo back in 1999, but getting there wasn't easy.We continue with a fresh part of our conversation into Mark Cuban before the wealth and fame. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You clearly were born with the salesman gene. I've read that when you were 12 years old, that you went door-to-door selling garbage bags because you wanted to get enough money to buy a pair of sneakers you liked?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So I mean, people would sign up and then the next week --

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes. When they ran out of garbage bags, it was 100 of them, and they weren't very good because we kept a bunch for years. When they ran out of their 100 garbage bags, they would just call, you know, and I would go deliver some more.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: OK. In 1995, you and a friend buy an audio online service that ends up becoming broadcast.com.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Started. Yes, started. Didn't buy it. We started.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Really? Because I had read somewhere that you --

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. They got that wrong. I know exactly where you're going. Yes, we started it.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: OK. What was the idea there?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: The idea there was we -- Todd Wagner and I, who's my partner, one of my best friends, went to Indiana University, and literally to listen to an IU basketball game in Dallas, Texas, we would call somebody in Bloomington, Indiana, one of our friends that were still there, and they would hold the radio to a speaker phone and we'd be on the other side of the speaker phone listening to the game.And when the internet started happening and I was a technology geek, I was like I can figure out a better way. So started with a computer in the second better of my house and we figured out how to do streaming. Back then we called it internet broadcasting. And it started with just on demand then it went to live, then it went to video, and the next thing you know, you know, we were dominating the multimedia on the internet business.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So four years later, four years later.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: That's it.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You sell to Yahoo.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: For $5.7 billion.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. It's my favorite number.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So how does it feel? At what age were you then?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: How old was I? That was -- I was 41 going on 42.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: How did it feel at age 41 to be a billionaire?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Really good.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Really, really good. I make no apologies for it whatsoever. I mean, look, the idea that the internet stock market was going to bananas at the right time for us is certainly luck but it took a lot of work and a lot of effort to get there.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So one of the things that a new billionaire can do is they can buy a sports team.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And within months, you go ahead and buy the Dallas Mavericks, NBA professional basketball team, for $275 million.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And the last I saw, it is valued at $2.7 billion.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Not bad, is it?(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So that's like 10 times. CUBANyou want to sell it, though, and I don't. I'm really hoping that it become a legacy company for my kids. Running a sports team in this day and age is not easy with social media there is as much hate as there is love if not more. But at the same time, basketball is a sport I'm passionate about. I love owning the Mavs. I love being part of the team and trying to win and the competitive side of it so hopefully that carries on to my kids.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Is it sort of boys and their toys? I mean is that --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes. I mean it's not a business first. I mean, I don't run it to make money. I mean, I get -- when there is a last-second shot, Spencer did when he hits a last second shot. I get to run on the floor and dog pile with everybody else. I get to go before the game, right, and I get to get shots up in any arena we're playing in but the idea that, you know, there is a basketball court that's about to play an NBA game and I get to just go out there and make 10 threes in a row. What's better than that?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Now that's the first thing you've said to me.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: I love it.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: For years you've given some money back to the NBA however.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: $3 million in fines.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Is that what it is now?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: That's what our crack research team says. Complaining about the refs, complaining to the refs. Has it been worth it?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, absolutely. There's been a lot of changes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: $3 million worth?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean, the therapy.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: The yelling and the screaming. You know, I'm typically really, really calm outside of a Mavs game but for some reason, during the game, that's when all -- everything just comes out. All the stress comes right out and sometimes the things I say if we lose, the NBA doesn't like. But I'm OK with that.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So we're showing pictures of you here. One of the pictures is you coming out on the court after a game. I think you got fined $100,000 for that. I mean is that really worth it to you?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, you got -- yes. (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But I mean, does it do any good or is it just?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. No. Rules have been changed. Rules have been changed.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Such as?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But when you do it, is it strategic, this will get the NBA's attention or you're just pissed?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: I know when I'm going to be fined.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You do?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes. Because they don't care if I'm boisterous or loud or crazy on the sidelines. They care if I say something in the media that they think might make the league look bad.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You've gotten into something of a running battle with Senator Elizabeth Warren and it started when you took her out or took her on for what you said demonizing people who are wealthy.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And she fired back.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN (D-MA): Mark Cuban and his kind need to pay their taxes, and we need to change the laws so they're not written just by the lobbyists for Mark Cuban and his buddies so that they don't get exploited so they don't get to take advantage of every one of the loopholes they've built in. We need to change the law. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You said recently, going back at her, part of this running war, that she is everything that's wrong with politics.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: So, first of all, Mark Cuban and his buddies. My buddies aren't rich. My buddies are my high school friends, my college friends. It's not like there's a collective of people who try to change tax laws. Second, I don't lobby anybody for changing tax laws. I wrote a blog post probably almost 20 years ago saying, after military service, the most patriotic thing you can do is pay your taxes. I have no problem.I think three, four years ago now, last time I checked I paid 19 percent in taxes and three -- the year after that I paid 29 percent in taxes. And I've said many times, if you want to take the top tax rate from 37 to 38, 39, I'm fine with that. Where she went wrong is, one, just without asking me, check with me, doing anything, right, you know, my kind. I mean, that's what's wrong with politics. When you demonize anybody. Look, she was a waitress. She deserves all the credit in the world. She busted her ass to go from being a waitress and starting and being a single parent to being a multimillionaire. God good for her but what about her kind? Should she be judged by just based off of her pocketbook? Was it OK to listen to me when I was poor and sleeping on the floor but not OK to listen to what I have to say because I'm wealthy now?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And what's the point that you're pandering to a certain group of voters?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Right. If, you know, that's what politics is today. Who can I cash aspersion? Who can I demonize to make them look like the bad guy so I look like the good one?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: All of which raises the question, Mark, will you consider again running for president?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, let me -- OK.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Wow, that was quick.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, real quick.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You considered it in 2020.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Yes,

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And you did play with it.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, for sure.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: For a while. And your family ended up voting no.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And now the question is 2024.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Why?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Because I'd have more impact outside. I think what I'm doing with Cost Plug Drugs is just a start. I think we can truly absolutely 10 years from now, when we look back you'll say Cost Plus Drugs was an inflection point in the changing of the entire pharmaceutical industry. We just revolutionize --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I mean, I'm not denigrating that in any way, shape or form.

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Do you think that's bigger than being president of the United States?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. Because I don't think -- you know, presidents take more credit for more thigs than they do and they're criticized for more things than they do, and I just don't think the president of the United States has near the impact as an entrepreneur in this particular industry can.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I think most people would say, and I think I have most people who just watch this show would say that you wear your success and your money, your wealth, lightly. That you seem to enjoy it the way they think they would enjoy it if they were this successful. Is it as cool and as fun as being Mark Cuban as it seems?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Ninety-nine percent of the time. Yes. The only downside is some of the pressure puts on my kids, being my, you know, being my child is sometimes not fair to them because they are already labeled as, you know, who I am as opposed to who they are and I'm sure you've dealt with the same thing in your sons. But -- you know, and then the other side is there is always a camera somewhere. I can't be that same idiot with my friends that I used to be, you know and that's sometimes --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes, but leave us on the positive side. What's the positive?

utterances.speaker: CUBAN
utterances.sentences: Oh, the positive side is everything else. Right? I mean, oh, my goodness, just being able to wake up every day knowing I can have an impact. Being able to wake up every day knowing that there is things that I can enjoy that I never dreamed I'd be able to do. I mean, look, I'm the luckiest son of a gun on the planet. You know, when I die, I want to come back as me. Let's put it that way.(LAUGHTER) (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Welcome back to WHO'S TALKING. There are not a lot of people in Hollywood whose names automatically bring a smile to your face but my next guest is one of them. George Clooney is one of the world's most recognizable actors and I started our conversation with what it's like to reach that level of fame. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I was thinking about star power and what it is that makes a movie star. Why do you think it is, seriously? Why do you think it is that makes all the rest of us feel better to watch someone like you?

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: I don't know if that's true. But I --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But like you or Julia, I know Spencer Tracy.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Well, Spencer Tracy is a great example.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Right. One of your --

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Absolute hero of mine. But, you know, sort of -- what was that senator who they were doing something about porn and he says I, you know, I don't know how to describe it but I know it when I see it.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: No. It was actually -- it was a Supreme Court justice, Potter Stewart.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: He is not the sexiest man alive.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: He is not two-time sexiest man alive, and he is a movie star, you can't take your eyes off of him.So I don't know what it is. There's something electric about that. You know, when I work with Julia, you can see it on her, you know, and it's very alive in the room, because she's sort of invested in things. And she's such a great -- she is a great friend, and I think a great person to be on the set with, too, you know. I don't know how to describe it, though. I know what it is, I look -- you can look at some actors over the years, who weren't necessarily even the best actors of their generation, but they were stars.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And do you think it's just something in their personality? Something in their aura that you just can't take your eyes off of them?

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: I think sometimes it starts with a, you know, whatever job, a really good job that someone can identify you. And for me, just -- you know, I worked for years and years and years, and then I got "ER," and suddenly, we were on a Thursday night and had a really great time slot, and it was a really great show and everything changed for me. My career changed and work changed and perceptions of me changed.  That wasn't -- it wasn't like I was some genius along the way. Ifinally was working in the right vehicle. So maybe sometimes it's about the vehicle. You know, Julia, was "Pretty Woman," I think. But I can't explain it. I don't quite know how it works. I know a lot of movie stars, and you know, and you're looking at them going, you know, when they walk in the room there, you can't take your eye off of them.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You've made some darker movies in recent years, including one literally about the end of the world, and I know a lot of people said to you, why don't you just be Cary Grant and make romantic comedies?Why is it after years of resistance, you have decided in this movie to be Cary Grant and make a rom-com?

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, I hadn't done one a long time, since 1996. I did "One Fine Day" when I did a sort of a straight up romantic-comedy, probably not my greatest vehicles along the way.I have to say, I got sent the script and you know, we've worked on -- there had been a lot of dark things going on in the world, and I always feel that films try to reflect that often. They're usually late because it takes a couple of years to make a film. It felt like we all needed a break. I needed a break. I needed to -- I needed it to be a little carefree. I needed something. You know, if you look back at during the Depression, for instance, romantic-comedies really flourished. I think people needed a break. I certainly know Julia and I were both, when we read it, we thought, "I need a breather here," and this was the perfect thing for us.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: As I say, in the movie, you and Julia play a couple that really do not like each other. And at one point you explain why the marriage fell apart, and you say, at the beginning, it was unreal, and then it got real.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You've now been married just recently, eight years.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: To your lovely wife, Amal.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: She's not here. I even looked around.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: I looked around making sure she is not here.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: This is not -- this is your life.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, no, she comes from behind.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Hi.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So is that what's happened with you and Amal? And is it real yet?

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: No. With any luck, it'll never be real. I feel incredibly lucky every day. You know, I feel like -- you know, I have in my wife someone who is my best friend and someone who I am terribly in love with.And it's -- you know, we -- probably because it happened for me later in life. I don't take any of that for granted, any moment of any day. And, we -- I think, we both really made a commitment to make sure that we understand how lucky we are. You know, I go through this a lot, and you and I've had conversations about this before. And I always talk about, you know, career. I cut tobacco for a living, you know. I've done you know, sold ladies shoes and insurance door-to- door and I understand what it is like to not have insurance and to, you know, live paycheck-to-paycheck or no check-to-no check. I understand how lucky I am in this -- in my career and things. And I also -- and in doing that, I also have learned how lucky I am in love, and it took me a while, but Amal walked in and changed everything.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You said at some point, suddenly, someone else's life becomes more important to you than your own. Is that -- is that it?

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Sure. Now, I've got two kids, so it's even worse as you know, you've got kids. It's -- yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You've got all of these people whose lives are more important than your life.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: It's really an exciting thing in life to be able to say and feel, really earnestly feel that their lives, my wife's life, my kids' life, is infinitely more important than mine and what they're doing in their lives and I know, parents all -- I'm not -- this is not a unique thing. I understand that.But, it is also important to always acknowledge it, you know.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: These are pictures of you with your dad...

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: With my dad.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: ... Nick Clooney who was a newsman.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And a very successful and able and crusading newsman. I'm going to ask this next question with full sense of the irony of me asking this of you. Was he a hard act to follow?

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes. Yes. And, and you know, and I know that my advantage over yours is I didn't follow him in somewhat of the same profession. So I could -- you know, actually, when I was very young, I studied journalism in college, and I wanted to be a journalist. I thought it was a really noble profession.And then early on, I got a couple of opportunities because I was Nick Clooney's son, to do just live remotes from you know, Bengals' football games and I was terrible at it. The door was open for me because my father was an anchorman. And so I got to jump ahead of other people, and I was terrible at it. And I realized I was always going to be compared to my father, and I needed to find something else besides that profession, because I was never going to -- I was never going to catch him. He was really good at it. And I admire so much the fact that you've taken on the job that you've taken on for so long because you know as I know, it is a hard act to follow. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Coming up, George's first big break and what he has learned from the big misses along the way.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: George Clooney has won two Academy Awards and countless other accolades, but it is likely none of it would have happened, except for a critical decision not to star in his own show.(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: In 1994, your age 33, you get your part as Doug Ross, Dr. Doug Ross, in the show "ER," and we're going to show two scenes first of all you in the ER saving somebody's life and then you saving a kid who has been trapped in a flooded tunnel.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: There you are.  (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP FROM "ER".)DR. DOUG ROSS, FICTIONAL CHARACTER: Okay, give me 360.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Charging.ROSS; And clear. Okay, he's stabilized. Let's go. You hold on, damnit. You hold on. You hold on. You hold on. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So, I like that, you emerging from the water as the savior with this kid.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: That's a --

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: I asked for that in my contract.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Did you say "I wanted to come out as the savior."

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: I mean, we were shooting that in Chicago, and you know, Chicago, how the weather is. It was in October, and we got there and it was daytime and we're shooting during the day, 70 degrees, and I was like, "This is going to be a cakewalk tonight when we're shooting out in the water."And it started snowing by the time we got there that night and it was just -- we were all wearing wetsuits and that poor kid was suffering like crazy for it, you know.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Beyond the story, this is in real life. If you could say something to that 33-year-old George Clooney, what would you say to him?

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: I would say -- well, you know, I don't know. I don't know that I'm any wiser than I was, you know, 25 years ago. I'm not quite sure I am. I wouldn't, you know, I would say to make sure that you enjoy it. I did, quite honestly.So, you know, I worked hard through that period of time. I worked seven days a week for five years, because I was doing films while I was doing the show. And I needed to because that's how I ended up having success in other parts of the industry. So, you know, now I can look back and say, maybe slow down or enjoy it, but at the time, it was really fun.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: At that moment, I did a little research, at age 33, you had been offered your own show.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And you decided to turn that down to do --  CLOONEY

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: To work with Steven Spielberg and to be part of an ensemble.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I mean, there were a lot of other big stars on that show, and as someone who I know, is so smart and so strategic about your career. Why?

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Well, the first thing is I'd been -- I had done seven television series at this point, and I had been kind of the second banana on most of them and none of them were very good, quite honestly and I wasn't very good and I'm not here to crap all over the shows. I wasn't particularly good.I needed to work, and you know, there's a funny thing actors do, which is when you're a young actor, particularly before -- television has changed a little bit. But when you're a young actor when I was growing up, everybody -- we're all movie actors. I'm a movie actor. I just happen to be doing television.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But this is a waystation to --

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Even though I'd never done a film, I'm a movie actor.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: I'm just doing TV. And so you just kind of took jobs, you know.And finally I got to a place where I said, well, I'm a TV actor, and so I better try to do better television. And this was for a lot less pay, but it was working with Spielberg and Creighton and Spielberg was just coming off of "Schindler's List" and "Jurassic Park" and it was a really good script, the part was a smallest part of all of the parts. But I, over my career fared very well in ensembles, quite honestly, and I like them. I think they work really well.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Then, at the depths of the Great Recession, you have another movie where you play a guy whose job it is to go around the country, laying people off in "Up in the Air."

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP FROM "UP IN THE AIR.")

utterances.speaker: NATALIE KEENER, FICTIONAL CHARACTER
utterances.sentences: We prepared the newly unemployed for the emotional and physical hurdles of job hunting while minimizing legal blowback.

utterances.speaker: RYAN BINGHAM, FICTIONAL CHARACTER
utterances.sentences: That's what we're selling. That's not what we're doing.

utterances.speaker: KEENER
utterances.sentences: Okay. What are we doing?  BINGHAMacross the river of dread until the point where hope is dimly visible, and then to stop the boat, shove in the water and make them swim. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So I want to ask you a technique question.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: How do you, in such a minimal way, so subtly communicate, frankly, so much? I mean, humor, cynicism, self-awareness, and you're not doing much, but it's all there.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: I think sometimes, actors get too much credit for things and I can prove it to you, because, for instance, it's script and director. That's all it is. It really is.I've been -- you know, I was kind of hailed as the worst Batman in the history of time. Fair enough, I was. The next film I did was "Out of Sight" which is probably the best reviewed film I've ever done and I'm good in it because the film was good and the script was good and the director was great.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You've had -- these are questions you ask and you think, "Jesus, how am I going to say this?" You've had a few clunkers?

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: In recent years.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: You think?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, okay, and you once said about Hollywood at some point, they're going to take away the toys. I know how this ends, I know how this works.Have you, in the course of your career ever been worried, maybe after one of those clunkers? They're going to stop letting me play with the toys.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Well, not yet. I will say this, I've had moments in my life, I did a TV show that I quit when I was a younger actor. I quit for the right reasons, the guy was a jerk, the producer, and was yelling to babies, you know, and I quit, and I sort of thought my career was over then.And someone who I'd been nice to years earlier, called me up and said, I've got a job for you, and sort of, you know, living well was kind of the best revenge in that. There have been plenty of times where you make mistakes, sometimes it's your own mistakes. Sometimes it's, you know, you'll get in a film that you think is going to be great and it doesn't work. Sometimes, you know, that's your own fault and sometimes it's other people's fault. You know, I've been lucky enough to still be allowed to do what I like to do.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Is that one of the reasons though, that you went into directing early on because if the acting thing doesn't work out, I've got another skill set here?

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: I started by producing and writing and directing because I thought, I don't want to worry about what some casting director thinks about how I am aging, you know, and be like, "Oh, he looks pretty old. Don't put them in this anymore." I knew that would come.So I did want to be in the industry that I love doing something different. But also, I'm more curious than that. You know, when you're acting in a film, you're basically one of the paints and when you're directing the film, you're the painter, and you get to pick and choose and it's infinitely more exciting and I've succeeded wildly and I've failed terribly at that as well. I've never learned anything from succeeding, ever. I've learned a lot from failing, and so I don't mind all of that. I like getting in and say well, let's muck it up a little bit.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Which lasts longer for you? The successes or the failures?

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: The failures.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Up next, we get a little personal. George opens up about his life after Hollywood and his proudest moment as a parent, which I promise will have you cracking up.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: In recent years, George Clooney has gone from one of Hollywood's most eligible bachelors to a happily married man with young twins. I asked him about life as a parent, but first his life outside Hollywood fighting for causes he hopes will make the world a better place.(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I try tried to get behind things that I think I could have, at least I can help bring attention to it. I can't change things. You know, I'm not -- we're another government, my wife and I. We try to get involved in things that we think we can bring, we can -- you know it's rolling that ball uphill towards that arc of justice, you know, and we fail, I fail most often. We've failed a lot in Darfur, failed a lot, quite honestly, but it's worth the journey and worth you know trying to --You look at the world and you go, look, we're all going to have -- we're all in this together now and we have to figure out ways to stand up for justice, which has to be waged. My wife and I talk about it all the time. It doesn't just happen, it has to be treated like war. Go to war, you arm yourself, you collect allies, you build an army. Well you have to do that with justice and peace as well. And so I'm a big believer in getting in and getting your -- getting up to your knees and trying to figure out where you can fit in in trying to help.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You say that your dad had one rule for you, which was take on the people who are more powerful than you and comfort, support, defend the people who are less powerful than you.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Sure. My family -- look, I -- you know, we're about the same age. I grew up in the 60s.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: No, we're not.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: We're not?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: No, we are not.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Okay, good.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I am considerably older than you.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Oh, well --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Which is why we ran through these movies of you, not TV shows of me.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Well, that's good. But I mean, growing up in a certain period of time, the 60s and 70s, particularly, you know, there was the Women's Rights Movement, the Civil Rights Movement. There was -- you know, there were so many things going on -- the anti-Vietnam movement -- there were so many things going on that you had to be involved. My parents were deeply involved.And, as I was growing up, I was taught, you know, if you're not in it, then you're not participating.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: How worried are you about our democracy?

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: I'm worried about it. I'm worried about the course name of America. I'm worried about how we celebrate unkindness now. So, I look at where we are at this sort, of course, of our discourse, and I find it to be worrying.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: How do you feel about the likely prospect of a Biden-Trump rematch in 2024?

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Well, look, it's all scary, right? Just because there is a there is a world where we could go back to where we were. I don't think it's as likely as people think, but I was wrong about the first election. You know, I didn't think people would -- I didn't think people would vote for someone who was so deeply flawed, you know?I mean, I know, Donald Trump. You know, I mean, that's the thing is people -- you know, I have his phone number in my phone book. He was the guy that came to the bars and asked me about which cocktail waitress was single, you know, that's who he was.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: This was back in the 90s.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: It wasn't that long, no. Back in the 2000s, quite honestly, and so there's this part of you that just goes, well, that guy shouldn't be President, but I was wrong, and he was and our democracy, I believe, paid a price, certainly around the world.And I worry about the possibility. I don't think it's as good as some people are afraid of, but I do worry about it. I think we're in a time where we need to -- we need some interesting candidates all around the board, you know.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Democratic side as well.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Sure. Yes. We need interesting candidates out there.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You are now 61 years old.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I read somewhere that you have talked about how many summers you have left? What do you want to do with the summers that you have left?

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: It's interesting. Well, my wife and I've had this conversation about, you know, we call it our Halcyon years. I said, listen, I'm 61, I can still play a little basketball, I can still hang you know, play sports and run around. But in 20 to 25 years, I'll be eighty, eighty-five years old. And then that's a real number. I'll be with a walker.I said, so we have to make sure that while I'm young, not her, that we're able to spend time doing other things besides just work, just trying to simplify to spend time with our kids, to spend time with our family.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You talk about your kids, Ella and Alexander, five years old.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You are a notorious prankster, and I read somewhere --  CLOONEY

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I read somewhere that he has learned from the master.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So, here's the question, what's the best prank he has pulled? Either on you or his sister or his mom or somebody?

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: The really good one was the I do a lot of like peanut butter and Nutella jokes, which just work great.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Is it true that you used to put Nutella in a diaper and then you'd sit there and eat it?CLOONEY Well, I wouldn't eat it. He would eat it, which is fantastic. I mean, that was a really good play. But now he has one where --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I don't think Amal -- I know Amal. I wouldn't think she would have found that enormously funny.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: She doesn't find it nearly as funny as I do.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Or Alexander.CLOONEY So Alexander walked in the other day, and he has put crunchy peanut butter on the side of his tennis shoes. And he comes he goes, "Pop." And he goes, "You smell poopoo," and I'm like, "No." We have a giant dog. And he looks at his shoe and he's got crunchy peanut on the side of the shoe and goes, "uh-oh," and I go, "uh-oh." And he reaches down and he goes like this. He goes "Oh, it's poop." Literally I wanted to -- I couldn't celebrate enough. I would have done a endzone dance. I was so happy.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, you may be 61, but you act more like 14.

utterances.speaker: CLOONEY
utterances.sentences: Well, isn't that the way? Is that the way you're supposed to do it?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes, it is.(END VIDEOTAPE)
